Viral Infections.name: Rabies (Hydrophobia)
Viral Infections.description: Rabies is a fatal viral disease that can affect any mammal. Canine rabies is a zoonotic concern due to the close relationship between dogs and humans. Vaccination is commonly required by law.
causes: Exposure to saliva from an infected animal

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure the dog is kept calm and hydrated, and manage any symptoms with the guidance of a veterinarian.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate consultation is crucial for post-exposure treatment and rabies immunoglobulin administration.

prevention: Keeping pets away from wild animals

Viral Infections.name: Canine Parvovirus
Viral Infections.description: A highly contagious virus affecting the gastrointestinal tract, especially in puppies.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide intravenous fluids to maintain hydration and administer medications to control vomiting and diarrhea. Isolation is important to prevent transmission.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate veterinary intervention is essential for aggressive supportive care and monitoring.

prevention: Disinfecting areas that could be contaminated

Viral Infections.name: Canine Coronavirus
Viral Infections.description: A usually asymptomatic or mild gastrointestinal disease. More severe in puppies.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide hydration and nutritional support, ensuring that the dog rests and is monitored for worsening symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian if symptoms do not improve or worsen.

prevention: Vaccination when recommended by a veterinarian

Bacterial Infections.name: Brucellosis
Bacterial Infections.description: A sexually transmitted disease causing uveitis, abortion, and orchitis.

treatment.Supportive Care: Maintain a clean environment and provide symptomatic treatment as directed by the veterinarian.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for accurate diagnosis and comprehensive treatment involving antibiotics.

Fungal Infections.name: Blastomycosis
Fungal Infections.description: A fungal infection affecting the eyes, brain, lungs, skin, or bones. More common in dogs than humans.
causes: Inhalation of spores from contaminated soil

treatment.Supportive Care: Administer supportive therapy as needed and monitor the dog for systemic complications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Seek veterinary diagnosis and treatment, potentially involving antifungal medication.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Osteoarthritis
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A common condition in dogs characterized by progressive deterioration of articular cartilage in the joints, causing pain and lameness.

treatment.Supportive Care: Administer pain management medications such as NSAIDs and provide joint supplements. Physical therapy and controlled exercise can help maintain joint function.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for customized pain relief and treatment plans including medications or surgical options.

prevention: Joint supplements as advised by a veterinarian

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Hip Dysplasia
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: An inherited disease characterized by abnormal development of the acetabulum and head of the femur, common in large breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide joint supplements, controlled exercise, and physical therapy to alleviate discomfort.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for an assessment to explore surgical and non-surgical treatment options.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Elbow Dysplasia
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A hereditary condition involving various issues in the elbow joint, common in large breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit activity and apply cold compresses to reduce inflammation. Provide joint support supplements.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for diagnosis and treatment that may include anti-inflammatories or surgery.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Luxating Patella
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A condition where the kneecap displaces from its normal position, more common in smaller breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Physical therapy, weight management, and exercises to strengthen surrounding muscles.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for assessment and to determine if surgery is needed.

prevention: Avoiding high-impact exercise in predisposed breeds

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Osteochondritis Dissecans (OCD)
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: Separation of immature articular cartilage from underlying bone, commonly seen in the stifle, elbow, shoulder, and hock.

treatment.Supportive Care: Restrict activity and provide joint support supplements as recommended.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to explore treatment options including surgery.

prevention: Avoiding rapid growth in puppies through controlled feeding

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Panosteitis
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A disease causing pain and shifting leg lameness in medium and large breed dogs, affecting the long bones.
symptoms: Lameness that shifts from leg to leg

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide pain relief with NSAIDs and limit physical activity during episodes.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian to rule out other conditions and ensure appropriate pain management.

prevention: Avoiding excessive exercise in growing puppies

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Legg–Calvé–Perthes Syndrome
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: Also known as Perthes disease, it is characterized by a deformity of the femoral head causing hip pain, primarily in small-breed puppies.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit weight-bearing activities and provide pain relief.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for diagnosis and to discuss potential surgical intervention.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Intervertebral Disk Disease (IVDD)
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: Degeneration and protrusion of intervertebral disks causing spinal cord compression, commonly seen in breeds like Dachshunds and Basset Hounds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Rest and pain management medications. Use of a back brace may help.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for diagnosis, and if necessary, discuss surgical options such as disk removal or decompression.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Craniomandibular Osteopathy
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A hereditary disease affecting the mandible and skull, mainly in West Highland White Terriers.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide pain management and ensure soft food to reduce jaw strain.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and supportive treatment.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Hypertrophic Osteopathy
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A bone disease secondary to lung disease, characterized by new bone formation on the long bones.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage pain and ensure comfort.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian to address the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

prevention: Routine veterinary check-ups to detect underlying conditions

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Hypertrophic Osteodystrophy
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: A bone disease affecting rapidly growing large breed dogs, causing pain and swelling of the metaphysis.
causes: Unknown, potentially nutritional or genetic factors

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide pain relief and maintain hydration.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for diagnostic evaluation and treatment plan.

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Spondylosis
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: Also known as spondylosis deformans, characterized by osteophyte growth on the vertebrae, usually asymptomatic.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide gentle exercise and ensure the dog remains active but not overworked.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian if symptoms progress or cause discomfort.

prevention: Regular exercise to maintain spinal health

Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.name: Masticatory Muscle Myositis (MMM)
Skeletal and Muscular Disorders.description: An inflammatory disease affecting jaw muscles, causing swelling and difficulty opening the mouth.

treatment.Supportive Care: Assist with eating by providing soft or liquid food.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for diagnosis and corticosteroid treatment.

Platelet Disorders.name: von Willebrand Disease
Platelet Disorders.description: A common inherited disease in dogs caused by a deficiency of the von Willebrand factor, which plays a crucial role in blood clotting.
causes: Genetic deficiency of von Willebrand factor
symptoms: Excessive bleeding after surgery or injury
Excessive bleeding during an estrous cycle

treatment.Supportive Care: Administering clotting aids, avoiding trauma, and limiting activities that could lead to injuries.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Critical for diagnosis, managing bleeding episodes, and prescribing medications like desmopressin when necessary.

prevention: Monitoring known carriers for bleeding tendencies

Platelet Disorders.name: Thrombocytopenia
Platelet Disorders.description: A condition characterized by a low platelet count, leading to spontaneous or prolonged bleeding.
symptoms: Prolonged bleeding after surgery or injury

treatment.Supportive Care: Maintaining hydration, managing underlying causes, and providing a stress-free environment.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Essential for accurate diagnosis and determining the appropriate treatment, including potential medications or transfusions.

prevention: Routine check-ups to monitor platelet levels

Platelet Disorders.name: Thrombocytosis
Platelet Disorders.description: A condition characterized by an excess of platelets. It may be physiologic, reactive, or due to a primary bone marrow disorder.
causes: Reactive to conditions such as cancer or blood loss
symptoms: May present with improper blood clotting if platelets do not function normally

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitoring platelet function and ensuring the dog remains hydrated and healthy.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Necessary to evaluate platelet levels and identify any underlying conditions that need treatment.

Platelet Disorders.name: Hemolytic Anemia
Platelet Disorders.description: A regenerative type of anemia where red blood cells are destroyed. The most significant type is immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (IMHA).
causes: Secondary to cancer, infection, drugs, or vaccinations

treatment.Supportive Care: Providing fluids, maintaining a warm and comfortable environment, and ensuring proper nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Critical for diagnosing the type and cause of anemia, initiating appropriate treatments like immunosuppressive therapy or blood transfusions.

prevention: Immediate attention to signs of pica or anemia

Heart Diseases.name: Degenerative (Myxomatous) Mitral Valve Disease
Heart Diseases.description: A common cause of congestive heart failure in dogs, especially small, older dogs. The valve leaflets become thickened and nodular, leading to regurgitation and volume overload of the left side of the heart.
Heart Diseases.prevention: Regular veterinary check-ups and monitoring for early signs in at-risk breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor fluid intake, reduce physical exertion
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian for a detailed treatment plan

Heart Diseases.name: Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
Heart Diseases.description: A disease of the heart muscle resulting in decreased contractility and dilation of the left ventricle and atrium, commonly leading to congestive heart failure.
Heart Diseases.prevention: Ensure a balanced diet rich in essential nutrients and regular cardiac health check-ups.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide a calm environment and manage diet
treatment.See Veterinarian: Essential for specific medication and monitoring

Heart Diseases.name: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)
Heart Diseases.description: Result of severe heart disease leading to fluid build-up in the lungs, around the lungs, or in the abdomen. Can be caused by mitral valve disease, DCM, congenital heart defects, or other conditions.
Heart Diseases.prevention: Maintain heartworm prevention, routine vet visits, and early treatment of any heart conditions.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit activity and provide comfortable sleeping positions
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate medical attention for management

Heart Diseases.name: Sick Sinus Syndrome
Heart Diseases.description: A condition marked by sinoatrial node dysfunction, resulting in fainting and abnormal heart rhythms.
Heart Diseases.prevention: Regular monitoring for early signs in predisposed breeds and minimizing stress.

treatment.Supportive Care: Minimize stress and monitor for fainting episodes
treatment.See Veterinarian: Necessary for diagnosis and possible pacemaker implantation

Heart Diseases.name: Subvalvular Aortic Stenosis (SAS)
Heart Diseases.description: A congenital condition where the left ventricular outflow tract is obstructed, leading to a heart murmur and exercise intolerance.
Heart Diseases.prevention: Breeding programs that screen for genetic heart conditions can reduce incidence.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor activity levels and provide a calm environment
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult for potential surgical or medical management

Nervous System.name: Syringomyelia
Nervous System.description: A condition where a fluid-filled sac develops in the spinal cord, often due to a Chiari I malformation, where an underdeveloped occipital bone affects spinal fluid circulation.
Nervous System.prevention: Breeding practices that screen for Chiari malformation can help reduce the incidence.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage pain and reduce stress
treatment.See Veterinarian: May require surgical intervention or medication to reduce fluid accumulation

Nervous System.name: Epilepsy
Nervous System.description: A disorder characterized by recurring seizures that can be idiopathic (inherited) or secondary to head trauma or CNS infections.
Nervous System.prevention: Regular health checks and avoidance of head trauma can help manage risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Maintain a safe environment during seizures
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiepileptic medication such as Phenobarbital

Nervous System.name: Rage Syndrome
Nervous System.description: A rare inherited seizure disorder marked by explosive aggression and focal neurological symptoms, linked to seizures in the temporal lobe.
Nervous System.prevention: Breeding controls and genetic testing may help reduce cases.

treatment.Supportive Care: Behavioral management
treatment.See Veterinarian: Use of antiepileptic drugs like Phenobarbital

Nervous System.name: Cerebellar Hypoplasia
Nervous System.description: An underdevelopment of the cerebellum, most commonly due to an in utero infection with canine herpesvirus.
Nervous System.prevention: Avoid exposure of pregnant dogs to the herpesvirus.

treatment.Supportive Care: Symptom management and physical therapy
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult for tailored treatment and supportive care

Nervous System.name: Polyneuropathy
Nervous System.description: A group of peripheral nerve disorders involving multiple nerves, often breed-related, affecting motor function.
Nervous System.prevention: Genetic screening and maintaining overall nerve health.

treatment.Supportive Care: Physical therapy to maintain muscle function
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medication and supportive care for underlying conditions

Nervous System.name: Canine Cognitive Dysfunction
Nervous System.description: A progressive condition similar to Alzheimer's disease in humans, affecting older dogs.
Nervous System.prevention: Mental stimulation and a healthy diet may slow progression.

treatment.Supportive Care: Cognitive training and environmental enrichment
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications to manage symptoms

Nervous System.name: Scotty Cramp
Nervous System.description: A condition in Scottish Terriers causing leg spasms due to serotonin metabolism disorder.
Nervous System.prevention: Breeding programs to avoid genetic carriers.

treatment.Supportive Care: Reduce stress and manage exercise
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medication may be recommended for severe cases

Nervous System.name: Cauda Equina Syndrome
Nervous System.description: Compression of the cauda equina due to narrowing of the lumbosacral vertebral canal, often seen in German Shepherd Dogs.
Nervous System.prevention: Maintain healthy joint and spinal health.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit activities that stress the spine
treatment.See Veterinarian: May require surgery or pain management

Nervous System.name: Tick Paralysis
Nervous System.description: A disease caused by a neurotoxin in the saliva of female ticks, leading to progressive paralysis.
Nervous System.prevention: Tick prevention through topical treatments and checking for ticks regularly.

treatment.Supportive Care: Remove ticks promptly
treatment.See Veterinarian: Supportive care and anti-toxin management

Nervous System.name: Dancing Dobermann Disease
Nervous System.description: A myopathy affecting the gastrocnemius muscle, characterized by flexing of one rear leg while standing.
Nervous System.prevention: Monitoring breeding lines may help reduce cases.

treatment.Supportive Care: Physical therapy and muscle strengthening exercises
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult for advanced treatment options

Nervous System.name: Granulomatous Meningoencephalitis (GME)
Nervous System.description: An inflammatory disease of the central nervous system, often affecting young and middle-aged female toy breeds.
Nervous System.prevention: Regular veterinary check-ups can assist with early detection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Anti-inflammatory treatment and monitoring
treatment.See Veterinarian: Corticosteroids and immunosuppressive therapy

Nervous System.name: Facial Nerve Paralysis
Nervous System.description: Paralysis of the facial nerve, often due to trauma or otitis media, leading to an inability to blink or facial drooping.
Nervous System.prevention: Protect ears from infection and avoid trauma.

treatment.Supportive Care: Eye protection and facial massage
treatment.See Veterinarian: Specific treatment for underlying cause

Nervous System.name: Laryngeal Paralysis
Nervous System.description: Paralysis of the larynx, leading to changes in voice and breathing difficulty, commonly seen in older large breeds.
Nervous System.prevention: Avoid stress on the throat and neck, maintain general health.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage stress and avoid overheating
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical intervention may be necessary

Nervous System.name: White Dog Shaker Syndrome
Nervous System.description: A syndrome causing full body tremors, most common in small white breeds such as Maltese and Poodles.
Nervous System.prevention: Regular veterinary care and monitoring for symptoms.

treatment.Supportive Care: Keep dog calm and avoid stress
treatment.See Veterinarian: Corticosteroids and antiepileptic drugs

Nervous System.name: Wobbler Disease
Nervous System.description: A condition involving cervical vertebrae instability, leading to weakness and an unsteady gait.
Nervous System.prevention: Avoid breeding affected individuals; monitor spine health.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage physical activity
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgery may be needed in severe cases

Nervous System.name: Cerebellar Abiotrophy
Nervous System.description: A condition caused by the degeneration of Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, leading to progressive ataxia.

treatment.Supportive Care: Assistive devices and physical therapy
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult for advanced care management

Eyes.name: Progressive Retinal Atrophy (PRA)
Eyes.description: A genetic disease of the retina causing progressive vision loss that eventually leads to blindness. It occurs in both eyes and is commonly seen in certain breeds.
Eyes.prevention: Genetic screening in breeding programs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Adapt the environment to assist the dog's mobility and comfort
treatment.See Veterinarian: Genetic counseling and regular eye check-ups

Eyes.name: Retinal Dysplasia
Eyes.description: An eye disease characterized by folds or rosettes in the retinal tissue. It is typically non-progressive and can be caused by genetics, viral infections, drugs, or vitamin A deficiency.
Eyes.prevention: Breeding programs focusing on genetic health.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitoring for any changes in vision
treatment.See Veterinarian: Management of any underlying contributing factors

Eyes.name: Sudden Acquired Retinal Degeneration (SARD)
Eyes.description: A condition causing sudden and permanent blindness. The cause is unknown but may involve autoimmune disease, toxins, or Cushing's disease.
causes: Unknown (possibly autoimmune, toxins, or Cushing's disease)
Eyes.prevention: There is no known prevention as the cause is largely unknown.

treatment.Supportive Care: Adapt living spaces for safety
treatment.See Veterinarian: Evaluation and potential management of underlying conditions

Eyes.name: Retinal Detachment
Eyes.description: A condition where the retina separates from the underlying tissue, potentially caused by genetic disorders, trauma, inflammation, or cancer.
Eyes.prevention: Prompt medical attention to trauma or underlying conditions.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit physical activity to avoid further damage
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medical or surgical intervention for reattachment

Eyes.name: Ectropion
Eyes.description: A condition where the eyelid folds outward, commonly affecting the lower lid. It is seen in breeds like the Cocker Spaniel, St. Bernard, Bloodhound, and Basset Hound.
Eyes.prevention: Regular eye check-ups, especially for predisposed breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Lubricating eye drops to reduce irritation
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical correction in severe cases

Eyes.name: Entropion
Eyes.description: A condition where the eyelid folds inward, causing the eyelashes or hair to rub on the eye. It is common in breeds like the Chow Chow, Shar Pei, St. Bernard, and Cocker Spaniel.
Eyes.prevention: Regular eye health monitoring, especially for affected breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Lubricating eye drops
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical correction for severe cases

Eyes.name: Distichia
Eyes.description: An abnormal growth of eyelashes from the meibomian gland or other spots on the eyelid. It may lead to eye irritation, squinting, and inflammation.
Eyes.prevention: There is no prevention, but early detection can help manage symptoms.

treatment.Supportive Care: Regular cleaning of the eye
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of abnormal lashes

Eyes.name: Chalazion
Eyes.description: A granuloma that forms in the eyelid due to blocked secretion of the meibomian gland. It can cause inflammation in the eyelid.
Eyes.prevention: Proper eyelid hygiene and addressing underlying infections.

treatment.Supportive Care: Warm compresses to reduce swelling
treatment.See Veterinarian: Incision or drainage if necessary

Eyes.name: Trichiasis
Eyes.description: A condition where hair grows in the wrong direction, often causing irritation to the eye. It commonly occurs in the lateral upper eyelid of breeds like the English Cocker Spaniel.
Eyes.prevention: Monitoring eye health, especially in predisposed breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Lubricating eye drops
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal or adjustment of hair growth

Eyes.name: Cataracts
Eyes.description: An opacity in the lens of the eye, often due to genetic predisposition or diabetes mellitus. Cataracts can result in partial or total vision loss.
Eyes.prevention: Manage diabetes and regular eye check-ups.

treatment.Supportive Care: None for reversal
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of cataracts

Eyes.name: Lens Luxation
Eyes.description: A displacement of the lens from its normal position, which can affect vision. Terrier breeds are especially predisposed.
Eyes.prevention: Genetic screening in breeding programs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Managing discomfort
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical repositioning or removal of the lens

Eyes.name: Nuclear Sclerosis
Eyes.description: A common age-related change where the center of the lens becomes hazy. It has little effect on vision and is often confused with cataracts.
symptoms: Bluish-grey haze in the center of the lens
Eyes.prevention: No specific prevention, but regular eye exams help distinguish from cataracts.

treatment.Supportive Care: None required
treatment.See Veterinarian: No treatment necessary for vision management

Eyes.name: Collie Eye Anomaly (CEA)
Eyes.description: A congenital, inherited, bilateral eye disease involving the retina, choroid, and sclera. It can cause blindness or remain mild. Common in breeds like the Collie, Shetland Sheepdog, and Australian Shepherd.
Eyes.prevention: Genetic screening in breeding programs to avoid inheritance.

treatment.Supportive Care: No specific treatment, monitoring for signs of progression
treatment.See Veterinarian: Management to slow progression and maintain vision

Eyes.name: Cherry Eye
Eyes.description: A condition where the gland of the third eyelid prolapses and becomes visible. Common in various breeds of dogs.
symptoms: Redness and swelling around the eye
Eyes.prevention: No prevention, but early detection can help prevent complications.

treatment.Supportive Care: No specific home treatment
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical correction or re-positioning of the gland

Eyes.name: Canine Glaucoma
Eyes.description: A condition characterized by increased pressure within the eye, potentially caused by abnormal drainage, lens luxation, uveitis, or cancer. Common in breeds like the Cocker Spaniel and Poodle.
Eyes.prevention: Routine eye exams for early detection, especially in predisposed breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Medication to reduce intraocular pressure
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical treatment or lifelong medication to manage pressure

Eyes.name: Ocular Melanosis (OM)
Eyes.description: A condition marked by an increase in melanocytes (pigment cells) in the iris, sclera, and surrounding structures. It is most commonly found in Cairn Terriers.
Eyes.prevention: Regular eye health monitoring, especially in predisposed breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: None required unless complications arise
treatment.See Veterinarian: Monitoring for signs of glaucoma or other eye issues

Eyes.name: Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca (Dry Eye)
Eyes.description: A condition where the dog’s eyes do not produce enough tears, leading to dryness and irritation. It can result in corneal ulcers and other complications.
Eyes.prevention: Regular monitoring for early signs in predisposed breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Lubricating eye drops and tear stimulants
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications or surgery in severe cases

Eyes.name: Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada Syndrome
Eyes.description: A syndrome characterized by uveitis (inflammation of the inner eye), poliosis (whitening of hair), and vitiligo (loss of pigment in the skin).
symptoms: Loss of pigment in the skin
Eyes.prevention: No known prevention, but early detection may help manage symptoms.

treatment.Supportive Care: Steroid medications to manage inflammation
treatment.See Veterinarian: Long-term immunosuppressive therapy

Eyes.name: Conjunctivitis
Eyes.description: Inflammation of the conjunctiva, often caused by mechanical irritation, allergies, or infections. It is common in dogs with conditions like entropion or trichiasis.
Eyes.prevention: Proper eye care and management of underlying conditions.

treatment.Supportive Care: Cleaning the eye and using lubricating drops
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics or anti-inflammatory medication for infections

Eyes.name: Eye Proptosis
Eyes.description: A condition where the eye is displaced forward and trapped by the eyelids, often resulting from trauma. Common in brachycephalic (short-nosed) breeds.
Eyes.prevention: Avoiding trauma to the face and eyes.

treatment.Supportive Care: Keep the eye moist with lubricating drops
treatment.See Veterinarian: Emergency repositioning and potential surgery

Eyes.name: Horner's Syndrome
Eyes.description: A syndrome caused by damage to the sympathetic innervation of the eye, leading to signs such as a sunken eye, small pupil, and drooping eyelid.
Eyes.prevention: Prompt treatment of underlying conditions or trauma.

treatment.Supportive Care: None required unless underlying causes are identified
treatment.See Veterinarian: Further diagnostic workup and treatment of the cause

Eyes.name: Optic Neuritis
Eyes.description: Inflammation of the optic nerves, often caused by granulomatous meningoencephalitis or infections.
Eyes.prevention: None specific, but early diagnosis can help manage complications.

treatment.Supportive Care: Steroid or anti-inflammatory medications
treatment.See Veterinarian: Treatment for the underlying cause

Eyes.name: Persistent Pupillary Membrane
Eyes.description: A condition involving remnants of fetal tissue that persist as strands across the pupil, sometimes obstructing vision.
Eyes.prevention: No specific prevention.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor for any vision loss
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal if vision is impaired

Ears.name: Ear Infection
Ears.description: A common condition in dogs, especially in breeds with hanging ears like Beagles or narrow ear canals like Cocker Spaniels. It can be caused by allergies, ear parasites, and hypothyroidism.
symptoms: Redness or swelling in the ear canal
Ears.prevention: Regular ear cleaning and dry ear care, especially in breeds prone to infections.

treatment.Supportive Care: Keep ears clean and dry
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotic or antifungal treatments, depending on the cause

Ears.name: Deafness
Ears.description: Deafness in dogs can be acquired or congenital. Acquired deafness is often due to chronic ear infections, certain medications, or age-related cochlea changes. Congenital deafness is sometimes genetic, especially in dogs with merle or white coats.
causes: Genetic factors (e.g., merle or white coat coloration)
Ears.prevention: Early detection and treatment of ear infections, and avoiding exposure to toxins or certain medications.

treatment.Supportive Care: Use of visual or tactile communication
treatment.See Veterinarian: Diagnostic tests to confirm the cause and manage symptoms

Ears.name: Fly Strike Dermatitis
Ears.description: A skin condition that occurs on the ears of dogs, caused by bites from the stable fly (Stomoxys calcitrans). It is most common on the tip and folds of the ear.
symptoms: Redness and irritation on ear tips and folds
Ears.prevention: Minimize exposure to flies, especially in outdoor areas.

treatment.Supportive Care: Topical treatments to relieve irritation
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotic or anti-inflammatory treatment if infection is present

Skin.name: Atopy
Skin.description: An allergy to substances that are inhaled or absorbed through the skin, often leading to itching. Affects up to 10% of dogs, especially in breeds like Labrador Retrievers, Golden Retrievers, and Shih Tzus.
symptoms: Redness or inflammation on underside, face, feet, and ears
Skin.prevention: Avoid exposure to known allergens where possible.

treatment.Supportive Care: Antihistamines, corticosteroids, and soothing topical treatments
treatment.See Veterinarian: Allergy testing and immunotherapy (allergen-specific desensitization)

Skin.name: Flea Allergy Dermatitis
Skin.description: The most common skin disease in dogs in the U.S., caused by sensitivity to flea saliva. It leads to intense itching and inflammation.
symptoms: Hair loss, particularly at the base of the tail
Skin.prevention: Flea control treatments and keeping the environment free from fleas.

treatment.Supportive Care: Flea treatments, anti-itch medication
treatment.See Veterinarian: Prescription flea preventatives and topical steroids

Skin.name: Food Allergy
Skin.description: A common cause of itching in dogs, often affecting the face, paws, and underside. Diagnosed by eliminating potential allergens with a hypoallergenic diet.
symptoms: Itching, especially on face, paws, and underside
Skin.prevention: Avoid exposure to known food allergens.

treatment.Supportive Care: Hypoallergenic diet
treatment.See Veterinarian: Allergy testing and tailored dietary recommendations

Skin.name: Follicular Dysplasia
Skin.description: A genetic disorder causing hair loss (alopecia) due to abnormal hair follicle structure.

treatment.Supportive Care: Topical treatments to manage symptoms
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications to reduce inflammation and promote skin health

Skin.name: Dermoid Sinus
Skin.description: A genetic skin condition that appears as lumps along the dorsal midline, caused by a congenital defect.
symptoms: Possible discharge or infection from the sinuses

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor for infection
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the sinus tract

Skin.name: Lick Granuloma
Skin.description: A skin condition caused by excessive licking of the lower leg, resulting in a thickened, firm, oval plaque.
causes: Excessive licking due to anxiety, boredom, or irritation
symptoms: Thickened, firm lesion on the lower leg
Skin.prevention: Address underlying causes of licking (e.g., anxiety, boredom).

treatment.Supportive Care: Bandaging the area, topical treatments to soothe the skin
treatment.See Veterinarian: Anti-anxiety medications or corticosteroids, antibiotics if infected

Skin.name: Pemphigus
Skin.description: An uncommon autoimmune skin disease that causes skin erosions and crusting, with pemphigus foliaceus being the most common form.
symptoms: Erosions and crusting of the skin
Skin.prevention: No known prevention for autoimmune diseases.

treatment.Supportive Care: Immunosuppressive medications (e.g., corticosteroids)
treatment.See Veterinarian: Long-term medication to control autoimmune response

Skin.name: Sebaceous Adenitis
Skin.description: An uncommon autoimmune skin disease, primarily affecting Akitas and Standard Poodles, that leads to inflammation of the sebaceous glands and hair loss.

treatment.Supportive Care: Medicated shampoos and oils
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immunosuppressive medications and antibiotics for infections

Skin.name: Dermal Fragility Syndrome
Skin.description: A rare genetic condition causing increased skin elasticity and poor wound healing.

treatment.Supportive Care: Gentle handling to avoid skin damage
treatment.See Veterinarian: Wound care and management

Skin.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
Skin.description: An autoimmune skin disease that primarily affects the nose, causing scaling and loss of pigment. It does not progress to systemic lupus erythematosus in dogs.
symptoms: Scaling and loss of pigment on the nose
Skin.prevention: Limit sun exposure, as UV rays may exacerbate symptoms.

treatment.Supportive Care: Topical treatments to manage skin lesions
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immunosuppressive medications and sun protection

Skin.name: Juvenile Cellulitis
Skin.description: Also known as puppy strangles, this disease affects puppies and is thought to have a hereditary link to the immune system.
symptoms: Pustules or scabs on the face and neck

treatment.Supportive Care: Anti-inflammatory medications
treatment.See Veterinarian: Corticosteroids and antibiotics if secondary infection occurs

Endocrine diseases.name: Diabetes Mellitus
Endocrine diseases.description: Type 1 diabetes in dogs is caused by a lack of insulin production due to the destruction of pancreatic beta cells. It can be caused by autoimmune diseases or severe pancreatitis.
Endocrine diseases.prevention: There is no preventive method; however, proper management of underlying causes can help control diabetes.

treatment.Insulin Therapy: Insulin replacement therapy is necessary for management
treatment.Diet: High fiber and complex carbohydrate diet

Endocrine diseases.name: Hypothyroidism
Endocrine diseases.description: The most common endocrine disorder in dogs, caused by autoimmune destruction or atrophy of the thyroid gland. It leads to insufficient production of thyroid hormones.
causes: Idiopathic atrophy of the thyroid gland
Endocrine diseases.prevention: There are no preventive measures for hypothyroidism, though early detection can help manage symptoms.

Endocrine diseases.name: Hyperthyroidism
Endocrine diseases.description: A rare condition caused by thyroid carcinoma (malignant tumor), leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones.
Endocrine diseases.prevention: There are no preventive measures; however, early diagnosis can help with treatment.

Endocrine diseases.name: Hypoadrenocorticism (Addison's Disease)
Endocrine diseases.description: A rare endocrine disorder caused by the destruction of the adrenal glands, leading to a reduction in glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.
Endocrine diseases.prevention: Prevention involves gradual tapering off steroid medications to avoid adrenal suppression.

Endocrine diseases.name: Cushing's Syndrome
Endocrine diseases.description: A condition caused by excessive cortisol production, often due to a pituitary tumor. It can also result from the overuse of steroid medications.
Endocrine diseases.prevention: Avoid excessive use of steroids and manage tumors early.

Endocrine diseases.name: Diabetes Insipidus
Endocrine diseases.description: A rare condition characterized by excessive thirst and urination due to a lack of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or the kidneys' inability to respond to it.
causes: Central diabetes insipidus (lack of ADH production)
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (kidney resistance to ADH)
Endocrine diseases.prevention: There are no preventive measures for diabetes insipidus.

Endocrine diseases.name: Acromegaly
Endocrine diseases.description: A hormonal condition caused by overproduction of growth hormone, typically in unspayed females or those on progesterone-based medications.
Endocrine diseases.prevention: Spaying females can prevent transient acromegaly caused by progesterone.

treatment.Somatostatin: Can be used to control growth hormone secretion

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Megaesophagus
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A condition characterized by low motility and dilation of the esophagus, often leading to regurgitation.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: No definitive prevention, but early diagnosis may help in management.

treatment.Dietary changes: Small, frequent meals, often in an upright position
treatment.Medications: Prokinetic drugs, antibiotics for secondary infections

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Gastric Dilatation Volvulus (Bloat)
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A life-threatening condition where the stomach becomes distended with air and may twist upon itself.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: Avoid feeding large meals immediately before exercise and consider prophylactic surgery for high-risk breeds.

treatment.Surgical intervention: Immediate surgery to untwist the stomach

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Foreign Body Obstruction
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A condition where an object becomes lodged in the gastrointestinal tract, often causing a blockage.
causes: Inability to pass objects through the pyloric sphincter
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: Avoiding access to small or sharp objects that can be swallowed.

treatment.Endoscopy: If the foreign body is in the stomach

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Anal Fistulae
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: Chronic draining tracts around the anus, most common in German Shepherds.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: No known prevention, though early treatment can help manage symptoms.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Exocrine Pancreatic Insufficiency
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A condition where the pancreas fails to produce adequate digestive enzymes, leading to malabsorption.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: There is no known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage the condition.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Pancreatitis
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: Inflammation of the pancreas, most common in overweight, middle-aged dogs.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: Maintaining a healthy weight and avoiding fatty foods.

treatment.Dietary modification: Low-fat diet once the acute phase is over

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A group of disorders characterized by inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Bilious Vomiting Syndrome
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: Vomiting caused by bile-induced inflammation of the stomach.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: Frequent small meals to prevent bile buildup.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Intussusception
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A condition where one part of the intestine telescopes into another, leading to obstruction.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: No known prevention, though managing underlying causes may help.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Lymphangiectasia
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A disease of the intestine characterized by chronic diarrhea and protein loss.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Hemorrhagic Gastroenteritis
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A sudden onset of vomiting and bloody diarrhea, often life-threatening.
Gastrointestinal Diseases.prevention: Avoiding dietary indiscretion and managing stress.

Gastrointestinal Diseases.name: Gallbladder Mucocele
Gastrointestinal Diseases.description: A condition where the gallbladder becomes filled with mucus and bile, leading to obstruction.

Kidney Diseases.name: Fanconi Syndrome
Kidney Diseases.description: A type of renal tubule disease commonly found in Basenjis, characterized by the inability to concentrate urine and the presence of glucose, protein, and amino acids in the urine.
symptoms: Presence of glucose, protein, and amino acids in urine
Kidney Diseases.prevention: No definitive prevention, but early detection and management can help slow progression.

Kidney Diseases.name: Kidney Failure
Kidney Diseases.description: A condition defined by the loss of about 75% of kidney function, leading to azotemia and low specific gravity of urine. It can be acute or chronic.
causes: Acute kidney injury (e.g., blood supply loss, hypercalcemia, toxins)
Chronic kidney failure (e.g., congenital, inherited, cancer, infection, hypertension, glomerulonephritis)
Kidney Diseases.prevention: Regular veterinary check-ups, maintaining hydration, and avoiding toxins.

treatment.Dietary changes: Special renal diets to support kidney health

Kidney Diseases.name: Glomerulonephritis
Kidney Diseases.description: A condition where immune complexes deposit in the glomeruli of the kidneys, leading to protein leakage into the urine. It may result from various infections or diseases.
Kidney Diseases.prevention: Managing underlying conditions such as infections or autoimmune diseases.

Kidney Diseases.name: Familial Renal Disease
Kidney Diseases.description: A rare cause of kidney failure in young dogs, most often related to breed-specific inherited conditions.
Kidney Diseases.prevention: Breeding management and genetic testing in high-risk breeds.

treatment.Symptomatic treatment: Hydration and management of kidney function

Kidney Diseases.name: Samoyed Hereditary Glomerulopathy (SHG)
Kidney Diseases.description: A hereditary noninflammatory renal disease affecting the glomeruli in Samoyeds. It is a model for hereditary nephritis in humans.
causes: Inherited genetic condition in Samoyed dogs
Kidney Diseases.prevention: Genetic testing in breeding programs to prevent transmission.

Urinary Bladder Diseases.name: Bladder Stones (Uroliths)
Urinary Bladder Diseases.description: Bladder stones are formed in the urinary bladder and can vary in size and number. They are commonly caused by infections, dietary factors, and genetics. Common types include struvite, calcium oxalate, urate, cystine, calcium phosphate, and silicate stones.
Urinary Bladder Diseases.prevention: Dietary management, regular urinary check-ups, and addressing underlying infections.

treatment.Dietary changes: Specialized diets to prevent stone formation

Urinary Bladder Diseases.name: Urinary Tract Infection (Cystitis)
Urinary Bladder Diseases.description: Urinary tract infection, or cystitis, is a common condition in dogs, usually caused by bacterial infections. It is characterized by inflammation of the bladder.
causes: Bacterial infections (e.g., E. coli, Staphylococcus spp., Proteus mirabilis)
Urinary Bladder Diseases.prevention: Maintaining proper hydration, regular urinalysis, and prompt treatment of infections.

Urinary Bladder Diseases.name: Urinary Incontinence
Urinary Bladder Diseases.description: Urinary incontinence refers to the leakage of urine, usually due to a weak urethral sphincter in adult dogs or congenital conditions like ectopic ureters in puppies.
causes: Hormonal imbalances (lack of estrogen in spayed females)
symptoms: Frequent licking of the genital area
Urinary Bladder Diseases.prevention: Spaying dogs with a risk of incontinence, early detection, and hormone replacement therapy.

treatment.Surgical correction: For ectopic ureters or severe cases

Reproductive Diseases.name: Prostate Disease
Reproductive Diseases.description: Prostate disease in dogs includes benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), prostatitis (infection of the prostate), cancer, and cysts and abscesses. BPH is the most common, found in older intact dogs. Prostatitis is often associated with BPH and is caused by bacterial infections.
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Castration can prevent BPH and reduce the risk of prostatitis and prostate cancer.

treatment.Surgery: For cysts, abscesses, or prostate cancer

Reproductive Diseases.name: Cryptorchidism
Reproductive Diseases.description: Cryptorchidism is when one testicle remains undescended, either in the abdomen or inguinal canal, past the normal stage of development. It is often a sex-limited autosomal recessive trait in dogs.
symptoms: One testicle is absent from the scrotum
Palpable testicle in the inguinal area or abdomen
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Genetic screening and early neutering in affected dogs.

Reproductive Diseases.name: False Pregnancy (Pseudocyesis)
Reproductive Diseases.description: False pregnancy is a common condition in intact female dogs, where they exhibit signs of pregnancy despite not being pregnant. This condition often resolves on its own but may require treatment in severe cases.
causes: Occurs in intact females after a heat cycle
symptoms: Appetite changes (loss of appetite or eating more)
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Spaying is the most effective prevention.

treatment.Hormonal therapy: To regulate prolactin and progesterone levels
treatment.Supportive care: Including reducing lactation and behavioral changes

Reproductive Diseases.name: Pyometra
Reproductive Diseases.description: Pyometra is a potentially fatal infection of the uterus that primarily affects unspayed female dogs. The condition typically occurs after the estrus cycle and is characterized by the accumulation of pus in the uterus.
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Spaying is the most effective prevention.

treatment.Surgery: Ovariohysterectomy (spaying) is the treatment of choice

Reproductive Diseases.name: Umbilical Hernia
Reproductive Diseases.description: An umbilical hernia occurs when the umbilical ring of the abdominal wall does not close properly, leading to a protrusion of abdominal contents. It is common and often seen in puppies.
causes: Traction on the umbilical cord or cutting the cord too close to the body
symptoms: Visible bulge near the belly button (umbilicus)
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Careful management during birth and proper umbilical cord care.

treatment.Surgery: Umbilical hernia repair to close the defect

Reproductive Diseases.name: Inguinal Hernia
Reproductive Diseases.description: Inguinal hernia is the protrusion of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal. It may occur as a congenital condition or as a result of injury or strain.
symptoms: Visible bulge in the groin area
Reproductive Diseases.prevention: Careful management of trauma and genetic screening.

treatment.Surgery: Inguinal hernia repair through surgical closure of the inguinal canal

Cancers.name: Canine Transmissible Venereal Tumor
Cancers.description: A tumor of the external genitalia, spread by sexual contact. More common in hot and humid climates.
Cancers.prevention: Avoiding unprotected sexual contact between dogs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Surgical removal of tumors
treatment.See Veterinarian: Chemotherapy or radiation therapy may be necessary

Cancers.name: Hemangiosarcoma
Cancers.description: An aggressive tumor that most often affects the heart, spleen, skin, subcutaneous tissues, and liver.
Cancers.prevention: Regular veterinary check-ups for early detection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management and stabilization
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy

Cancers.name: Osteosarcoma
Cancers.description: An aggressive bone tumor that commonly spreads to the lungs. More common in large and giant breed dogs.
Cancers.prevention: There are no known preventive measures.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management
treatment.See Veterinarian: Amputation of the affected limb, chemotherapy

Cancers.name: Histiocytoma
Cancers.description: A benign skin tumor more frequent in young dogs (<4 years), often regresses without treatment.
symptoms: Red or inflamed skin around the tumor

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor the tumor, as it may regress on its own
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal if necessary

Cancers.name: Malignant Histiocytosis (Histiocytic Sarcoma)
Cancers.description: An aggressive cancer found primarily in certain breeds like Bernese Mountain Dogs, Rottweilers, Golden Retrievers, and Flat-Coated Retrievers. It infiltrates various organs.
Cancers.prevention: Genetic counseling and responsible breeding practices.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management and supportive care
treatment.See Veterinarian: Chemotherapy or radiation therapy

Cancers.name: Mast Cell Tumor
Cancers.description: A tumor that usually occurs in the skin but can also spread to the liver, spleen, or bone marrow.
symptoms: Firm, raised lumps under the skin
Cancers.prevention: Regular skin checks and early detection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage secondary infections or complications
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal, chemotherapy

Cancers.name: Lymphoma
Cancers.description: A malignant cancer affecting the lymphatic system. The most common form in dogs is multicentric, involving the lymph nodes.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms
treatment.See Veterinarian: Chemotherapy

Cancers.name: Fibrosarcoma
Cancers.description: A malignant tumor most commonly found in the mouth, less commonly in the skin, subcutis, and bones.
Cancers.prevention: Regular veterinary check-ups for early detection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy

Behavioral.name: Pica
Behavioral.description: Pica is an appetite for, or the behavior of eating, non-nutritive substances like sand, coal, soil, chalk, or paper. It can be dangerous and may lead to poisoning or gastrointestinal obstruction.
causes: Poisoning from toxins like tetraethyllead or PCBs
symptoms: Eating non-nutritive substances like dirt, sand, or paper
Behavioral.prevention: Ensure a balanced diet, provide stimulation, and prevent access to harmful substances.

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure proper hydration and monitor for any signs of poisoning or blockage.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Test for anemia, gastrointestinal obstructions, or poisoning; treat with dietary adjustments, medication, or behavioral therapy.

Behavioral.name: Coprophagia
Behavioral.description: Coprophagia is the ingestion of feces, either its own or another dog’s. It may be caused by medical conditions or behavioral issues and can lead to infections or internal parasites.
Behavioral.prevention: Provide proper nutrition, eliminate access to feces, and address any behavioral issues.

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure proper hydration and treat any gastrointestinal upset.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Behavioral modification therapy, feces taste alteration, and possible medical treatments for underlying conditions.

Environmental.name: Sensitivity to Anesthesia
Environmental.description: Sighthounds are most commonly documented for having anesthetic concerns, especially with ultra-short-acting thiobarbiturates like thiopental. They often experience prolonged recovery times after anesthesia.
symptoms: Slower return to normal behavior post-surgery
Environmental.prevention: Use alternative anesthetics or adjust dosage based on breed and individual needs. Ensure close monitoring during and after anesthesia.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide extended recovery time and continuous monitoring of vital signs.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Adjust anesthesia protocol, consider using anesthetic alternatives for sensitive breeds.

Environmental.name: Heat Stroke
Environmental.description: Heat stroke is a dangerous condition that can occur in dogs, especially in flat-faced or giant breeds, due to high temperatures, lack of water, or strenuous exercise. It can cause vomiting, diarrhea, collapse, and difficulty breathing.
Environmental.prevention: Ensure access to fresh water, avoid excessive exercise in hot weather, and provide shade or cool environments for susceptible breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Cool the dog using wet towels, fans, and intravenous fluid therapy.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate cooling interventions, controlled water intake, and monitoring for complications like gastric dilatation volvulus (bloat).

Environmental.name: Foxtail and Sandbur Penetration
Environmental.description: Foxtails and sandburs can penetrate the skin or mouth lining, migrating through tissues and causing abscesses and draining tracts.
causes: Penetration into skin or mucous membranes
symptoms: Draining tracts on skin or in the mouth
Environmental.prevention: Avoid areas with foxtails and sandburs, and regularly check pets for foreign objects after outdoor activities.

treatment.Supportive Care: Clean the affected area to prevent infection, and monitor for any signs of swelling or discharge.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the foreign object and drainage of abscesses if necessary.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Acetaminophen Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Acetaminophen (paracetamol, Tylenol) can cause liver damage in dogs. The toxic dose is 150 mg/kg.
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Keep acetaminophen out of reach of pets, and avoid giving dogs human medications.

treatment.Supportive Care: Activated charcoal may be used to limit absorption.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate veterinary care for antidote treatment and liver support.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Ibuprofen Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Ibuprofen (Advil) can cause gastrointestinal irritation, stomach ulcers, and kidney damage in dogs.
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Avoid giving ibuprofen to dogs and keep it out of their reach.

treatment.Supportive Care: Administering fluids and anti-ulcer medications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate care to address kidney function and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Naproxen Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Naproxen (Aleve) has a long half-life in dogs and can cause gastrointestinal irritation, anemia, melena, and vomiting.
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Keep naproxen and other NSAIDs out of reach of pets.

treatment.Supportive Care: Fluid therapy, blood transfusions if necessary.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate veterinary attention to manage symptoms and monitor for gastrointestinal bleeding.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Antifreeze Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Antifreeze is very dangerous to dogs, causing central nervous system depression and acute kidney injury. Treatment is most effective within eight hours of ingestion.
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Ensure antifreeze is stored safely and cleaned up promptly.

treatment.Supportive Care: Administration of antidotes (such as fomepizole) and intravenous fluids.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate veterinary treatment within hours of ingestion for best chance of recovery.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Rodenticide Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Rodenticide poisoning commonly occurs from ingestion of anticoagulant rodenticides. It leads to excessive bleeding. Other types may cause hypercalcemia or CNS signs.
causes: Ingestion of mouse or rat poison (e.g., brodifacoum, bromadiolone, cholecalciferol, bromethalin)
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Store rodenticides safely and use pet-safe alternatives.

treatment.Supportive Care: Vitamin K supplementation for anticoagulant poisonings.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate treatment based on rodenticide type, such as intravenous fluids, anticonvulsants, or calcium therapy.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Insecticide Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Insecticides used for flea and tick prevention may contain organophosphates or carbamates, which can cause toxicity in dogs.
causes: Exposure to insecticides containing organophosphates or carbamates
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Use pet-safe insecticides and follow label instructions carefully.

treatment.Supportive Care: Administer fluids and atropine to counteract toxicity.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Veterinary care to manage symptoms and prevent fatal complications.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Chocolate Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Chocolate contains theobromine and caffeine, which are toxic to dogs. Baker's chocolate is the most dangerous form.
causes: Ingestion of chocolate (especially dark, semi-sweet, or baker's chocolate)
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Keep chocolate and cocoa products out of reach of dogs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Activated charcoal to limit absorption and intravenous fluids.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate care for severe symptoms such as seizures or heart arrhythmias.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Lead Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Lead poisoning occurs from ingestion of lead-based paint or objects containing lead. It causes neurological symptoms and gastrointestinal upset.
causes: Ingestion of lead-based paint or lead objects
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Avoid exposure to lead-containing materials and ensure safe environments for pets.

treatment.Supportive Care: Chelation therapy to remove lead from the system.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate treatment and monitoring for neurological and gastrointestinal symptoms.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Grape and Raisin Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Grapes and raisins can cause kidney failure in dogs. The exact toxic compound is unknown.
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Avoid giving grapes or raisins to dogs and keep them out of reach.

treatment.Supportive Care: Intravenous fluids and monitoring of kidney function.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate veterinary care to address potential kidney damage.

Poison and Overdoses.name: Garlic, Onion, and Chive Poisoning
Poison and Overdoses.description: Garlic, onions, and chives cause hemolytic anemia in dogs, leading to the destruction of red blood cells.
causes: Ingestion of raw, cooked, or powdered garlic, onions, or chives
Poison and Overdoses.prevention: Avoid feeding garlic, onions, or chives to dogs in any form.

treatment.Supportive Care: Fluid therapy and blood transfusions if necessary.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Immediate treatment to address hemolytic anemia and red blood cell destruction.

Miscellaneous.name: Vestibular Disease
Miscellaneous.description: Vestibular disease is an uncommon condition in older dogs, often idiopathic, but it can be caused by otitis interna, tumors, or encephalitis. It affects the dog's balance and coordination.
Miscellaneous.prevention: There is no clear prevention for idiopathic vestibular disease. Early detection and treatment of ear infections and tumors may help reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide supportive care and monitor the dog's condition. Most cases resolve within a few days to a few weeks.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Veterinary consultation may be required for diagnosis and management of any underlying causes such as infections or tumors.

Miscellaneous.name: Molera (Open Fontanelle)
Miscellaneous.description: Molera is a condition found in toy breeds like Chihuahuas, characterized by a soft spot on the skull. It may be associated with hydrocephalus or be a normal finding in certain breeds.
symptoms: Visible soft spot (fontanelle) on the skull
Miscellaneous.prevention: Genetic screening and responsible breeding practices can reduce the incidence in certain breeds.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor for signs of neurological issues. If associated with hydrocephalus, treatment may involve managing fluid buildup in the brain.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Consult a veterinarian if there are concerns about hydrocephalus or other neurological issues.

Miscellaneous.name: Anal Gland Problems
Miscellaneous.description: Anal gland issues are common in dogs and may involve impaction, infection, or abscessation. These glands are normally emptied during defecation.
symptoms: Excessive licking of the anal area
Pain or swelling around the anus
Miscellaneous.prevention: Regular monitoring and expressing the anal glands, if necessary, may help prevent impaction.

treatment.Supportive Care: Warm compresses and gentle massage may help alleviate impaction. For infections or abscesses, antibiotics may be required.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Veterinary care is needed for persistent or severe cases. Surgery may be required for abscessed glands.

Miscellaneous.name: Shar Pei Fever
Miscellaneous.description: Shar Pei fever is a condition in Shar Peis characterized by recurring fever and swelling of the hocks, which can lead to renal and liver failure.
causes: Genetic predisposition in Shar Pei breed
Miscellaneous.prevention: There is no clear prevention, but responsible breeding practices can help reduce the occurrence in Shar Pei dogs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Anti-inflammatory medications may help manage fever and swelling.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Veterinary intervention is crucial, as renal and liver failure can be life-threatening.

Miscellaneous.name: Liver Failure
Miscellaneous.description: Liver failure in dogs can result from bacterial or viral infections, toxins, cancer, copper storage diseases, or may be idiopathic.
Miscellaneous.prevention: Avoid exposure to toxins and ensure proper veterinary care for infections and liver diseases.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide supportive care, such as hydration and nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: A veterinarian may recommend medications, surgery, or other treatments depending on the underlying cause.

Miscellaneous.name: Dental Disease
Miscellaneous.description: Dental disease, especially gingivitis and periodontitis, is common in dogs and can lead to tooth loss if untreated.
Miscellaneous.prevention: Regular brushing, dental chews, and professional dental cleanings can help prevent dental disease.

treatment.Supportive Care: Regular brushing and the use of dental products can help manage oral hygiene.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Professional dental cleanings and treatment for any periodontal disease are necessary.

Miscellaneous.name: Portosystemic Shunt
Miscellaneous.description: A portosystemic shunt is a bypass of the liver's circulatory system and can be either congenital or acquired.
Miscellaneous.prevention: Genetic screening in breeds at risk can help identify congenital cases.

treatment.Supportive Care: Medications to manage symptoms and prevent complications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical correction is often recommended for congenital cases.

Miscellaneous.name: Perineal Hernia
Miscellaneous.description: A perineal hernia is a condition in which abdominal contents protrude through the pelvic diaphragm, causing swelling near the anus.
causes: Weakness in the pelvic diaphragm muscles
Miscellaneous.prevention: Early intervention and surgical repair can prevent worsening of the condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor the condition and manage any discomfort.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical repair is typically required to correct the hernia.

Cats.name: Aggressive Fibromatosis
Cats.description: Aggressive fibromatosis is a rare condition in cats characterized by the development of fibrous tissue tumors that can invade surrounding tissues.
symptoms: Lumps or masses under the skin
Pain or tenderness in the affected area
Cats.prevention: There is no known prevention, but early detection can help manage the condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management and monitoring of the tumor size.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the tumor or other treatments like radiation therapy may be necessary.

Cats.name: Aspergillosis
Cats.description: Aspergillosis is a fungal infection caused by the Aspergillus species, affecting the nasal cavity or sinuses of cats.
Cats.prevention: Reducing exposure to damp environments and fungal spores may help reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Antifungal medications to treat the infection.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Diagnosis and appropriate antifungal therapy are crucial.

Cats.name: Avian Influenza in Cats
Cats.description: Avian influenza is a viral infection that can affect cats, often acquired by exposure to infected birds.
causes: Contact with infected birds or their droppings
Cats.prevention: Avoiding exposure to infected birds and maintaining good hygiene can help prevent infection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Rest and fluid therapy to manage symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiviral medications may be prescribed if caught early.

Cats.name: Bladder Cancer
Cats.description: Bladder cancer, also known as transitional cell carcinoma, is a malignant tumor affecting the urinary bladder of cats.
Cats.prevention: Minimizing exposure to toxins and ensuring a healthy diet can reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms such as pain and blood in the urine.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal or chemotherapy may be needed for treatment.

Cats.name: Bone Cancer
Cats.description: Bone cancer in cats is most often osteosarcoma, a malignant tumor that typically affects the limbs.
causes: Trauma or injury to the bones
Cats.prevention: There is no specific prevention, but early detection and treatment are important.

treatment.Supportive Care: Pain management and anti-inflammatory medications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the tumor, followed by chemotherapy or radiation.

Cats.name: Cancer
Cats.description: Cancer in cats can manifest in various forms such as lymphoma, mammary tumors, and squamous cell carcinoma.
symptoms: Lumps or masses under the skin
Cats.prevention: Minimizing exposure to carcinogens and regular vet checkups can help detect cancer early.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms like pain and weight loss.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal, chemotherapy, or radiation depending on the type of cancer.

Cats.name: Cat Worm Infections
Cats.description: Cat worm infections, such as roundworms, hookworms, and tapeworms, are common parasitic infections in cats.
causes: Ingestion of infected fleas or rodents
symptoms: Visible worms in the stool or vomit
Cats.prevention: Regular deworming and flea control are important for prevention.

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure hydration and proper nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Deworming medications to eliminate the parasites.

Cats.name: Cat Flu (Upper Respiratory Infection)
Cats.description: Cat flu is an upper respiratory infection caused by various viruses and bacteria, such as Bordetella bronchiseptica and Chlamydophila felis.
Cats.prevention: Vaccination and good hygiene can reduce the risk of cat flu.

treatment.Supportive Care: Hydration, nutrition, and symptom management.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiviral medications or antibiotics may be needed for secondary infections.

Cats.name: Cat-Scratch Disease
Cats.description: Cat-scratch disease is a bacterial infection caused by *Bartonella henselae*, usually transmitted through a scratch or bite from an infected cat.
Cats.prevention: Preventing bites and scratches from cats, especially kittens, can reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms such as fever and swelling.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics are typically required for treatment.

Cats.name: Cat Skin Disorders
Cats.description: Cat skin disorders encompass a range of conditions, including dermatitis, fungal infections, and allergies.
symptoms: Redness or swelling of the skin
Cats.prevention: Regular grooming and flea prevention can help maintain healthy skin.

treatment.Supportive Care: Topical treatments and symptom relief.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Veterinary examination to identify the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

Cats.name: Central Retinal Degeneration
Cats.description: Central retinal degeneration is a condition affecting the retina of cats, leading to vision loss, particularly in older cats.
Cats.prevention: There is no known prevention, but regular eye exams may detect early signs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide a safe environment for the cat to navigate.
treatment.See Veterinarian: No cure, but management of the condition may be possible.

Cats.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
Cats.description: Chronic kidney disease is a common condition in older cats, where the kidneys gradually lose function.
Cats.prevention: Regular veterinary checkups and early detection of kidney issues can help manage the condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Fluid therapy and specialized diets.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medication to manage symptoms and slow disease progression.

Cats.name: Fading Kitten Syndrome
Cats.description: Fading kitten syndrome is a broad term for neonatal decline and death in kittens, often caused by infections, congenital malformations, or environmental and nutritional deficits.
Cats.prevention: Providing proper care, warmth, and nutrition to neonatal kittens can help prevent this condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Keep kittens warm, hydrated, and properly fed.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Treat underlying infections or malformations as needed.

Cats.name: Feline Acne
Cats.description: Feline acne is a condition where blackheads or pimples appear on a cat's chin, often due to clogged hair follicles.
symptoms: Redness or swelling around the chin
Cats.prevention: Regular grooming and cleaning of the chin area can help prevent feline acne.

treatment.Supportive Care: Gentle cleaning of the chin with non-irritating cleansers.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Topical antibiotics or other treatments for infection may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Feline Asthma
Cats.description: Feline asthma is a respiratory condition where inflammation and narrowing of the airways lead to difficulty breathing, often triggered by allergens.
Cats.prevention: Avoiding allergens and controlling environmental factors can reduce asthma flare-ups.

treatment.Supportive Care: Control symptoms with bronchodilators and corticosteroids.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Inhalers or systemic medications may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Feline Cognitive Dysfunction
Cats.description: Feline cognitive dysfunction is similar to dementia in humans, with cognitive decline in older cats affecting their behavior and functioning.
causes: Loss of neurons and brain plasticity
Cats.prevention: Mental stimulation and proper diet may help slow the progression of cognitive dysfunction.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide a consistent routine and environmental enrichment.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications like selegiline may help manage symptoms.

Cats.name: Feline Coronavirus
Cats.description: Feline coronavirus is a viral infection that can cause mild gastrointestinal signs, but may also lead to the more serious condition known as feline infectious peritonitis (FIP).
Cats.prevention: Good hygiene and minimizing exposure to infected cats can help prevent infection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms with hydration and nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: FIP may require antiviral medications, but treatment is generally limited.

Cats.name: Feline Cystitis
Cats.description: Feline cystitis is inflammation of the bladder, often caused by infections, stress, or other underlying conditions.
Cats.prevention: Providing a stress-free environment and proper hydration can help prevent cystitis.

treatment.Supportive Care: Encourage water intake and reduce stress.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics or medications to reduce inflammation may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Feline Cutaneous Asthenia
Cats.description: Feline cutaneous asthenia is a rare genetic disorder causing the skin to be excessively fragile and prone to tearing.
Cats.prevention: This is a congenital condition, and prevention is not possible.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide wound care and avoid skin trauma.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Careful handling to prevent injury and management of any skin tears.

Cats.name: Feline Distemper
Cats.description: Feline distemper, caused by the feline parvovirus, is a highly contagious and often fatal viral disease affecting young cats.
Cats.prevention: Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent feline distemper.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide hydration and nutritional support.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiviral medications and supportive care are used to treat infected cats.

Cats.name: Feline Foamy Virus
Cats.description: Feline foamy virus is a retrovirus that can cause chronic, mild respiratory symptoms and affect the immune system.
Cats.prevention: No vaccine or specific prevention, but minimizing exposure to infected cats may reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage respiratory symptoms and monitor overall health.
treatment.See Veterinarian: No specific antiviral treatment, but supportive care can help manage symptoms.

Cats.name: Feline Hepatic Lipidosis
Cats.description: Feline hepatic lipidosis, also known as fatty liver disease, occurs when there is excessive fat accumulation in the liver, typically due to rapid weight loss or anorexia.
symptoms: Yellowing of the eyes or gums (jaundice)
Cats.prevention: Prevent obesity and encourage healthy, consistent feeding habits.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide a high-quality diet and ensure adequate nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Tube feeding and medications to support liver function.

Cats.name: Feline Hyperadrenocorticism
Cats.description: Feline hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing's disease, occurs when the adrenal glands produce excessive cortisol, leading to various systemic issues.
Cats.prevention: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help manage the condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms through medications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of tumors or medications to control cortisol production.

Cats.name: Feline Hyperaldosteronism
Cats.description: Feline hyperaldosteronism is a condition where the adrenal glands produce too much aldosterone, leading to high blood pressure and electrolyte imbalances.
Cats.prevention: There is no known prevention, but early detection and treatment can manage symptoms.

treatment.Supportive Care: Medications to control blood pressure and electrolyte balance.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of tumors or medications to control aldosterone production.

Cats.name: Feline Hyperesthesia Syndrome
Cats.description: Feline hyperesthesia syndrome is a neurological disorder causing abnormal behaviors such as self-mutilation and excessive grooming.
Cats.prevention: Stress reduction techniques and providing a calm environment may help.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide a calm environment and ensure the cat is mentally stimulated.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications like antidepressants or anti-anxiety drugs may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Feline Hyperthyroidism
Cats.description: Feline hyperthyroidism is a common endocrine disorder where the thyroid gland produces excessive thyroid hormone, leading to increased metabolism.
causes: Benign tumors of the thyroid gland
Cats.prevention: No known prevention, but early detection and treatment can help.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms with a special diet and medications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the thyroid tumor or radioactive iodine treatment.

Cats.name: Feline Hypoadrenocorticism
Cats.description: Feline hypoadrenocorticism, also known as Addison's disease, occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol and aldosterone.
causes: Immune-mediated destruction of the adrenal glands
Cats.prevention: No known prevention, but early diagnosis can help with management.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide hormone replacement therapy.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy.

Cats.name: Feline Immunodeficiency Virus
Cats.description: Feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV) is a viral infection that weakens a cat's immune system, making it more susceptible to infections.
Cats.prevention: Limit exposure to FIV-infected cats and vaccination (where available).

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage secondary infections and provide antiviral medications.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics for secondary infections and immune support.

Cats.name: Feline Infectious Anemia
Cats.description: Feline infectious anemia is caused by a blood parasite that destroys red blood cells, leading to anemia.
causes: Infection with the parasite Mycoplasma haemofelis
Cats.prevention: Preventing flea infestations and limiting exposure to infected animals can help.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide fluids and monitor for signs of anemia.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics like doxycycline may be prescribed to treat the infection.

Cats.name: Feline Infectious Peritonitis
Cats.description: Feline infectious peritonitis (FIP) is a viral disease caused by certain strains of feline coronavirus, leading to systemic inflammation.
Cats.prevention: No vaccine for FIP is 100% effective, but reducing exposure to infected cats can reduce risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide nutritional support and manage symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiviral drugs like GS-441524 may be used to treat FIP in some cases.

Cats.name: Feline Leprosy Syndrome
Cats.description: Feline leprosy syndrome is caused by the bacterium *Mycobacterium lepraemurium*, resulting in granulomatous skin lesions.
Cats.prevention: Minimizing exposure to infected rodents and improving hygiene can help reduce the risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor skin lesions and provide proper wound care.
