treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics like rifampicin may be used for treatment.

Cats.name: Feline Leptospirosis
Cats.description: Feline leptospirosis is a bacterial infection caused by *Leptospira* species, affecting the kidneys and liver.
Cats.prevention: Vaccination can help prevent leptospirosis, especially in areas with high exposure.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide fluids and electrolytes to support kidney function.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics like doxycycline may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Feline Leukemia Virus
Cats.description: Feline leukemia virus (FeLV) is a retrovirus that weakens the immune system and increases the risk of cancer in cats.
causes: Exposure to FeLV-infected cats through saliva, nasal secretions, or bite wounds
Cats.prevention: Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent FeLV infection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor for secondary infections and provide supportive nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: There is no cure, but antiviral drugs may help manage symptoms.

Cats.name: Feline Lower Urinary Tract Disease
Cats.description: Feline lower urinary tract disease (FLUTD) is a term for a variety of urinary problems in cats, including cystitis and urethral obstruction.
Cats.prevention: Providing fresh water, stress reduction, and a proper diet can help prevent FLUTD.

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure proper hydration and manage stress.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics or surgery may be necessary for certain underlying causes.

Cats.name: Feline Lymphoma
Cats.description: Feline lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphoid tissue, commonly affecting the gastrointestinal tract and lymph nodes.
causes: Chronic viral infections, such as FeLV or FIV
Cats.prevention: No specific prevention, but reducing exposure to viral infections may lower risk.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide supportive care and manage symptoms of the disease.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Chemotherapy or radiation therapy may be used for treatment.

Cats.name: Feline Odontoclastic Resorptive Lesion
Cats.description: Feline odontoclastic resorptive lesions (FORLs) are painful dental conditions where the tooth structure is resorbed by the body.
causes: Unknown, but may be related to dental disease or immune-mediated response
Cats.prevention: Regular dental checkups and good oral hygiene can help prevent FORLs.

treatment.Supportive Care: Maintain oral hygiene and avoid triggering pain.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Tooth extraction or other dental treatments may be required.

Cats.name: Feline Panleukopenia
Cats.description: Feline panleukopenia is a highly contagious viral disease that affects the gastrointestinal, immune, and nervous systems of cats.
Cats.prevention: Vaccination is highly effective in preventing feline panleukopenia.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide fluids and electrolytes to combat dehydration.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiviral drugs and antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infections.

Cats.name: Feline Sarcoma Virus
Cats.description: Feline sarcoma virus is a retrovirus that causes tumors, often linked with vaccination in previously infected cats.
symptoms: Pain at the site of the tumor
Cats.prevention: Vaccination with an inactivated vaccine can reduce the risk of infection.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms and pain.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of tumors or chemotherapy may be used for treatment.

Cats.name: Feline Spongiform Encephalopathy
Cats.description: Feline spongiform encephalopathy is a prion disease that causes neurological degeneration and is related to mad cow disease.
Cats.prevention: Avoid feeding cats raw meat that could be contaminated with prions.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms and ensure the cat's comfort.
treatment.See Veterinarian: There is no cure for prion diseases.

Cats.name: Feline Viral Enteritis
Cats.description: Feline viral enteritis, caused by feline calicivirus or feline parvovirus, leads to inflammation of the intestines and gastrointestinal distress.
Cats.prevention: Vaccination can prevent most viral enteritis infections in cats.

treatment.Supportive Care: Hydration and nutritional support are essential.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics and antiviral treatments may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
Cats.description: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a heart disease in cats that causes thickening of the heart muscles, reducing the heart's ability to pump blood.
causes: Secondary to hyperthyroidism or high blood pressure
Cats.prevention: There is no known prevention, but early detection and management can improve the cat's quality of life.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide comfortable rest and manage heart failure symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Medications like beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Leishmaniasis
Cats.description: Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by *Leishmania* species, transmitted by sandflies, affecting the skin, organs, and immune system.
causes: Infection by *Leishmania* parasites via sandfly bites
Cats.prevention: Avoid exposure to sandflies, especially in endemic areas.

treatment.Supportive Care: Ensure hydration and manage kidney function.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antiprotozoal medications like miltefosine or allopurinol may be used.

Cats.name: Luxating Patella
Cats.description: A luxating patella occurs when the kneecap (patella) slips out of its normal position, leading to joint instability and pain.
causes: Injury or trauma to the knee
symptoms: Pain or stiffness in the leg
Cats.prevention: There is no surefire way to prevent luxating patella, but maintaining a healthy weight can help.

treatment.Supportive Care: Limit activity and provide pain relief.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgery may be required to correct the luxation.

Cats.name: Lyme Disease
Cats.description: Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness caused by *Borrelia* bacteria, typically affecting joints and the heart.
Cats.prevention: Use tick preventatives and avoid areas with heavy tick infestations.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide pain relief and manage inflammation.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotics like doxycycline may be used to treat Lyme disease.

Cats.name: Lymphocytopenia
Cats.description: Lymphocytopenia is a condition where there is an abnormally low number of lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) in the blood.
Cats.prevention: Maintain a healthy immune system and limit exposure to infections.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide immune system support and manage underlying causes.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause of the lymphocytopenia.

Cats.name: Mastocytoma
Cats.description: Mastocytoma is a type of tumor formed from mast cells, which can be benign or malignant, affecting skin or internal organs.
symptoms: Lumps or masses on the skin
Cats.prevention: No known prevention, but early detection and treatment can improve outcomes.

treatment.Supportive Care: Monitor for changes in the tumor's size and symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgical removal of the tumor or chemotherapy may be needed.

Cats.name: Miliary Dermatitis
Cats.description: Miliary dermatitis is a skin condition in cats characterized by scabs, lesions, and itching, often due to allergies or parasites.
symptoms: Scabs and crusts on the skin
Cats.prevention: Use flea preventatives and address allergies to prevent flare-ups.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide anti-itch medications and improve skin hygiene.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Corticosteroids, antihistamines, or antibiotics may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Otitis Externa in Animals
Cats.description: Otitis externa is an infection or inflammation of the outer ear canal, commonly caused by bacteria, yeast, or parasites.
symptoms: Redness or swelling of the ear canal
Cats.prevention: Regular ear cleaning and proper hygiene can help prevent infections.

treatment.Supportive Care: Clean the ears and apply topical treatments.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antibiotic or antifungal medications may be prescribed.

Cats.name: Paragonimus
Cats.description: Paragonimiasis is caused by *Paragonimus* lung flukes, leading to respiratory issues and organ damage.
Cats.prevention: Avoid feeding raw freshwater crustaceans to cats.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide respiratory support and manage symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Anthelmintic drugs like praziquantel may be used.

Cats.name: Polyneuropathy in Dogs and Cats
Cats.description: Polyneuropathy is a condition affecting multiple peripheral nerves, causing weakness, paralysis, and sensory loss.
Cats.prevention: Early detection and management of underlying conditions can help.

treatment.Supportive Care: Provide physical therapy and manage symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Treatment depends on the underlying cause and may involve medications.

Cats.name: Portosystemic Shunt
Cats.description: A portosystemic shunt is a vascular condition where blood bypasses the liver, leading to a buildup of toxins in the bloodstream.
causes: Congenital defects in the blood vessels
Cats.prevention: No known prevention, but surgical correction may improve the condition.

treatment.Supportive Care: Manage symptoms and ensure proper nutrition.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Surgery to close the shunt is typically required.

Cats.name: Protothecosis
Cats.description: Protothecosis is a rare infection caused by *Prototheca* algae, often affecting the skin, eyes, and internal organs.
causes: Exposure to contaminated water or soil
Cats.prevention: Avoid exposure to contaminated environments and improve hygiene.

treatment.Supportive Care: Treat secondary infections and manage symptoms.
treatment.See Veterinarian: Antifungal medications may be required.
